articles.headline: Obama Sees ’67 Borders as Starting Point for Peace Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama said that a lasting peace would require two states with secure borders in a speech Thursday that sought to harness the change unfolding in the region.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that a lasting peace would require two states with secure borders in a speech Thursday that sought to harness the change unfolding in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking to capture a moment of epochal change in the Arab world, began a new effort on Thursday to break the stalemate in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, setting out a new starting point for negotiations on the region’s most intractable problem.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Study Sees Way to Win Spam Fight
articles.snippet: If a handful of companies refused to authorize online credit card payments for spam-advertised products, the money supporting the system would be cut off, a researcher said.
articles.abstract: If a handful of companies refused to authorize online credit card payments for spam-advertised products, the money supporting the system would be cut off, a researcher said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, a team of computer scientists at two University of California campuses has been looking deeply into the nature of spam, the billions of unwanted e-mail messages generated by networks of zombie computers controlled by the rogue programs called botnets. They even coined a term, “spamalytics,” to describe their work.

articles.headline: Capitalists Who Fear Free Markets
articles.snippet: Japanese executives were outraged at the prospect of banks taking losses on loans to the company that produced a nuclear catastrophe. This used to be how free markets worked.
articles.abstract: Japanese executives were outraged at the prospect of banks taking losses on loans to the company that produced a nuclear catastrophe. This used to be how free markets worked.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capitalism is supposed to produce losses on bad investments.

articles.headline: A Former Basketball Prodigy, Bereft of All but His Memories
articles.snippet: Lewis Brown seemed destined for stardom in the N.B.A. Decades later, he sleeps on Los Angeles sidewalks and washes car windows.
articles.abstract: Lewis Brown seemed destined for stardom in the N.B.A. Decades later, he sleeps on Los Angeles sidewalks and washes car windows.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Stephen Turner pulled his silver Mercedes into the Mobil station on a gritty stretch of Hollywood near Vine Street and Santa Monica Boulevard, he did not immediately recognize the gigantic man with Windex who ambled over and offered to wash his windows for a tip.

articles.headline: Obama and Netanyahu, Distrustful Allies, Meet
articles.snippet: When they met Friday, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel faced a turning point in a relationship that was not warm to begin with.
articles.abstract: When they met Friday, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel faced a turning point in a relationship that was not warm to begin with.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel heads to the White House on Friday for the seventh meeting since President Obama took office, the two men are facing a turning point in a relationship that has never been warm.

articles.headline: Make My Bed? But You Say the World’s Ending
articles.snippet: A prophecy that Saturday is Judgment Day, and the start of the five-month end of the world, is dividing families.
articles.abstract: A prophecy that Saturday is Judgment Day, and the start of the five-month end of the world, is dividing families.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Haddad children of Middletown, Md., have a lot on their minds: school projects, SATs, weekend parties. And parents who believe the earth will begin to self-destruct on Saturday.

articles.headline: At I.M.F., Men on Prowl and Women on Guard
articles.snippet: The fund’s sexual norms are markedly different from those of Washington, leaving its female employees at risk of harassment.
articles.abstract: The fund’s sexual norms are markedly different from those of Washington, leaving its female employees at risk of harassment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is an international island in the midst of the American capital, a sharp-elbowed place ruled by alpha male economists. The days are long, and employees are regularly pressed together for weeks on end during overseas “missions.” It is a climate in which romances often flourish — and lines are sometimes crossed.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
